ry 18, 2016
												The game and music are absolutely beautiful, but I think this is the rare game that would benefit by being a more traditional hidden object game. Looking for the items is nice, and there's a hint system. But then you hit the "puzzles" which are a who's who of the most boring Adventure game tropes: a game of Memory, Simon Says, a couple of simple jigsaw puzzles, a "turn the things to make various paths line up", draughts (the peg game from Cracker Barrel), and one of those "turn the dials to match everything up, but as you try to match them it messes the others up". At best, these kinds of puzzles add very little to a game, but at worst, like here, they add a completely unnecesary level of boredome and frustration. I'm all for "difficult" games like Dark Souls, but this game should have stuck the relaxing formula of other hidden object games.

												Horribly designed game. Controls are confusing. Don't let the amazing art sell you on this game, it is not fun. A lot of the game is clicking, clicking, clicking. The puzzles give you zero direction.  A lot of game elements that are necessary to advance I discovered by boringly clicking around the screen to see if anything would happen. Unless your time is absolutely worthless do not invest it in this game.Not to mention, NO SAVES.  So if you are stuck in a level and you need to stop gaming for whatever reason, you literally have to start over since your only pause options are to go to the main menu or quit the game. I mean its mind boggling how many design flaws this game has while still managing to have a popular rating.

												I am not sure, if i should recommend this game. I was expecting game similar to Botanicula or Machinarium. Well, this is little different. It is more like hidden object game with puzzles, and insects. At the beginning, you will probably don't know what to do. Well, just find some insect and click on it. You will receive "quest" to find some hidden object. After completing few of these, you will get to the puzzle (logic puzzle, so you will need brain and patience).Game is really not too long, of course, it is indie. Game time is longer because of slow movement of your "character". Yes, you are actually control and move with your bug. That is probably only major con of this game, because you will have to move from one frame to another quite often.Only thing you need for this game is mouse, keyboard not needed.And yes, i am recommending it, price is not too high, music is good, puzzles are quite challenging, and whole game is pretty interesting, because (at least for me) it is something new, i have never seen game like this. content:
ry 4, 2016
												I absolutely love this game.  It's simple, it's short, and it's very relaxing to play.  I finished the whole thing in one sitting and was left wanting so much more.  While I'm not typically a fan of the find-the-thing game category, this one was beautiful.  It's exotic, innocent, the art is great and the music matches it exquisitely.  I feel like I ripped them off for paying so little.  It's only good for maybe an hour or two of actual play time but good god it's fun while it lasts.  The only downside, and I say this with no disparagement, is that some of the puzzles are not self-evident.  This isn't usually too much of a condemnation except that the game provides virtually no instructions at any point.  Of course, there's Google.  If you're at an absolute loss, do that.  There's a brief how to move sequence at the very beginning and the rest is up for you to figure out.  That being said, just get it.  It's so cheap.  There's really no way to go wrong with this one.  Even if it was just an art and music pack without a game at all it'd still be worthwhile.  If I can pay a dollar for over an hour of childlike wonder then I just won and that's exactly what Morphopolis brings to the table in the most beautiful, multicoloured and delightful way possible.  It's such a beautifully and richly put together game that I can't recommend it enough.

content:
r 24, 2015
												Positives:-The music is very relaxing.-The art is pretty.-Some of the puzzles are pretty fun, and you feel pretty smart for having solved them.-Nice if you like "find the hidden object"-type games.Negatives:-The controls for moving are crap.  Half the time you won't even realize you can go somewhere until you accidentally hold the mouse in the wrong area.  Other times, your bug keeps moving back and forth in the same spot as you try to find the place that'll make it go not just right, but right and downwards.  Sometimes you'll try clicking an object and end up moving your bug back over to the other screen for no apparent reason, even though you weren't clicking in that direction.-On a similar note, you are SLOW.  Slow, slow, slow, slow, SLOW.  Which wouldn't be SO bad, but since you're constantly moving back and forth between screens (using the same crummy controls) to find stuff you missed, it's just unbearable.  I feel like the game would have been at least a half an hour shorter if I could change screens faster.-So much random clicking to figure out what's important.  See, you don't actually find out what you need to collect until you click on something, like another bug, or a plant.  Sorta like they're giving you a quest.  Usually it's easy enough to figure out what needs clicking, but other times, you have no freaking idea how you're supposed to progress without taking a hint.-By level three, you'll start to recognize that the weird orange orbs are gonna need collecting before you can burrow into your next target's brain.  But no, you can't grab anything you know you're gonna need until after the 'quest' is given to you, forcing you to slowly, SLOWLY backtrack through all of the screens to grab them.  I don't mean to sound impatient, but God.  Crawl across the screen a little faster, bug.  Come on!  Hustle, hustle!-No idea where the "pathways" to the next screen are.  Have fun crawling (SLOWLY) across the screen, only to realize it's a dead end.  Then crawl (SLOWLY) back, not sure whether there's another screen, or if you're just bad at finding items.-Did I mention that you're slow?  Because you're slow.  SO FREAKING SLOW.-A couple puzzles are really annoying for the wrong reasons.  For example, the flower puzzle gives you no indication of the controls.  I spent ages clicking around and hoping something would happen, but nope!  It's actually a Chinese Checkers-style puzzle where you have to try and get all but one of the seed thingies to disappear, but without a walkthrough, I never would have figured out the rules and controls.  Figuring out what the freaking puzzle is isn't a puzzle.-No mid-level saves.  Levels aren't usually that long, but if you get stuck on something and call it quits for the night, have fun slowly, slowly, SLOWLY crawling across the screen several more times to complete the initial collection quests again.  SLOWLY.-I don't know if I just accidentally skipped it, or what (in which case it shouldn't be so easy to accidentally skip, because I'm not gonna freaking replay that last puzzle just to see it) but I went into the place I was supposed to go, and... That was it.  The game just ended.  I got an achievement, and then I was back at the menu.  Ghosts 'n' Goblins had a better ending than that!Summary:If you can get it on sale and really, REALLY like hidden object games, it might be worth it, but there are plenty of free games on the internet that aren't so, well, SLOW.  Seriously, I'm not kidding, it's really gonna get on your nerves.  Don't even think about paying the full five dollars for this.  I mean, I appreciate the effort the developers put into it, and everything, but this isn't worth two dollars and fifty cents per hour.

												The atmospheric soundtrack and the very beautiful visual environment art attracted my interest and kept me playing the game from the beginning till the end.The game lasts around 3 hours (maybe much less if you are used to solving puzzles) and its divided in 5 levels/stages in which there are 8 puzzles in total. Some of them are easy and some needs time and good attention/focus to solve them. The last one is more challenging, something like a soft version of Rubik's cube (but with insects)!At the gameplay you take the role of an insect that evolves/transforms after each level/stage of the game. Its a point and click game, you don't use keyboard, and you collect various of objects to feed them to some other insects that are blocking your way forward and during this you will encounter to solve these 8 puzzles that I mention before.TL;DR: Its a nice point and click adventure and puzzle game with very beautiful art and atmospheric soundtrack. It lasts around 2-3 hours and it has 5 levels and 8 puzzles in total. If it worths the full price... idk, it depends on the person. I bought it -95% only to farm the cards but I really liked the game and I played it till the end!Cons: Its really short game. It could have had more levels and puzzles.9/10

												As far as a game goes, this is not a very good one. As far as art, visual, and music ... that is a totally different story.The "gameplay" is very simple, and I'm not sure I would call it a "puzzle game" so much a find it. The music has a nice peaceful tone to it through the entire thing, and the visuals largely speak for themselves - beautiful. The story, and, yes, there is technically a story, is very strange, as well as simple, but effective when you think about it for a couple seconds. Morphopolis something to look at and admire, but not really interact with.  Not something I can recomend ... as a game. It is, howerver, something I can recomend as a short, peaceful experience that many people might find enjoyable. Take that as you will.

content:
5, 2015
												The game points on the music and the graphic.The music is simply awesome .... this is why I left the intro menu for 10 + minutes even if the tutorial arrow wanted me to click on the first puzzle so badly. The tutorial is short, basicly you have to click everywhere. The thing that is not showed in the short tutorial is that you have different maps and you'll reach them by moving your bug in that direction (sometimes it bugs a bit .... but you know, it's a game of bugs so they wanted friends XD).The game is quite easy both in the mechanic and game itself but it's still cute and interesting in some of its parts. In 2 hours it was sadly finished.... I want to start it again....Some puzzles where tricky because you need to use your brain and try to click slide or what else (click and slide stop).There are no bosses or evil insects here in this game, everything is really peaceful. You climb leaves flowers and insect themselves to help the others with their own issues by clicking the required items to collect them and bring them to the bug in need.The music is really awesome with the hang drum or pan, but after a while it can be boring if you'll spend a lot of time searching THAT tiny little item that you cannot see.The morphism of the insect is not an evolution of your starting little bug, as I've thought and maybe you too, but after you finish a level, you'll use a different one.Overall I love it and I complitely recommend this game, thoug I was hoping it has more than 5 levels Y_Y...

content:
er 29, 2015
												Morphopolis is an atmospheric game where you partially control an insect in an environment, collecting specific items by clicking on them, somewhat reminiscient of those old I Spy games. I certainly had a bit of a nostalgia hard-on while playing this game, full disclaimer on that one.I'd certainly say Morphopolis is quite therapeutic (unless you hate bugs), it has calming music, a vibrant environment that somehow feels huge, empty, and filled to the brim at the same time through its artistic use of the whole bug-world. There are plenty of times where you'll feel like the game is moving way too slow, and you will be stumped heavily on a puzzle or two here and there, perhaps to a point of rage, but in the end it makes you feel more accomplished. There even is a noticable progression between levels which gives you an air on familiarity in a new, strange environment.In the end, the game doesn't take too long to beat. But the apprehension and depiction of the whole game makes it feel longer, it gives you a feeling of being accomplished and completed. It's not a wonderful, 10/10 game, but for someone who's willing to take the time and mild frustration to complete the game, it can be a nice gaming/art experience.Is ok.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
er 29, 2015
												This game is odd, but in a good way.I can't tell what it's trying to be; whether it's a child's game, with dark, underlying themes, or whether it's an adventure into a mystical world just below normal human perception. But whatever it is, it's incredible. The puzzles were mostly easy (with the exception of the trickier final puzzle) and the gameplay was point and click, which searching aspects. But this, for me, was less of a game, and more of an experience. The art was absolutely awesome, and gave the world a unique and intriguing twist I haven't seen in a story game before.Should you buy it? That depends. If you're the kind of person who sits down for five minutes, leaves, and comes back, don't buy this. But if you like to take your time, and involve yourself in a game, this story without words would appeal to you like no other.The soundtrack made me just sit down and listen to the music, while the screen displayed just a menu, for about five minutes before starting the game. Each environment gave me a new sense of accomplishment, and I just look back on it and smile. That is, until I play it again.It is a short game, but it will change you.

er 30, 2015
												While the game art is indeed really beautiful, I sadly can't say the same thing for the gameplay.Character movement is painfully slow. I understand that it's supposed to be a relaxing game, but come on.The "hold-click this part of the screen to make your bug move to a general direction of where you're clicking at" PnC system is really awkward to do, causing the bug to sometimes end up dancing back and forth, confused of where it should go.The roots/pipes puzzle made almost no sense, while the other puzzles on the other hand are pretty okay. The flower draughts could use a bit of an in-game hint because NOT EVERYONE HAS PLAYED DRAUGHTS BEFORE.Some hidden objects are "too well-hidden", rendering looking for one without a hint is almost impossible. But that was probably just me.The "story" itself. What is this game about? An insect version of the body snatcher?Still, despite all the gripes on the gameplay, it was indeed an eye-pleasing experience. I'm glad it was also very cheap.

												-Already worth to get just for the atmosphere, music and art (obviously, if these are not important to you, then the major attraction here is lost on you)- Some will mention the lack of a story as a negative, but I feel it is part of the artistic aesthetic here. If there was explanatory text, it would pull you right out of mentioned atmosphere...And any intelligent human should understand what this is about while playing anyway.- Unfortunately, the controls get weird a few times, making it slower to progress by mere fact of your insect not going where you want it to.- Perhaps it could be a little longer.- Maybe it's just me, but the difficulty curve was strange, the game is very easy throughout, and then bamm, the last puzzle is quite time-consuming measured to all others before.

content:
er 26, 2015
												8/10 objective rating PROS:- Visually rich- Puzzles are varied enough- Soundtrack is pleasant to listen to- Sound design is solid- PriceCONS:- A little short (can be completed in 2-3 hours)- May take the entire first level to understand how this game wants to be played (there are no word prompts so some may find it difficult to understand what is being asked of them)- Some may find the pacing slow---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Morphopolis isn't the most challenging game I've played, nor is it the most interesting "story" wise, but I really enjoyed the art style and the overall feel. The music playing throughout was excellent and very pleasant to listen to. It varies with each level but sounds like one cohesive series.It IS a slow paced game, with 5 levels taking about 2 hours, but I still liked this, as it allowed me to really soak in the artistry and look a everything in detail. That being said, there were times I was sighing at the slowness of the insect I was controlling when I went up a plant for the 4th time. You will have to crawl back and forth between areas often.There isn't a proper tutorial and without word prompting, it was initially difficult to understand what the game wanted me to do. There was also no indication of what my insect character's "powers" were so I got stuck a few times and wasted time going between spots looking for things that I could not see without using said "powers" I discovered these abilities entirely by accident. Note that this could just be my fault and not the game's. This was my first game of this genre since the 90's and maybe I just required a little more hand-holding than most for the beginning.Adjust expectations before starting this game and I think anyone who likes puzzle games will thoroughly enjoy Morphopolis. If you expect action and puzzles that really get you scratching your head for 30 minutes each, you will likely be disappointed!Would have loved 10 levels instead of 5 so I could spend a little more time in this world, but for a quarter (yes, just 25 cents!) I definitely got my money's worth!

												Horribly designed game. Controls are confusing. Don't let the amazing art sell you on this game, it is not fun. A lot of the game is clicking, clicking, clicking. The puzzles give you zero direction.  A lot of game elements that are necessary to advance I discovered by boringly clicking around the screen to see if anything would happen. Unless your time is absolutely worthless do not invest it in this game.Not to mention, NO SAVES.  So if you are stuck in a level and you need to stop gaming for whatever reason, you literally have to start over since your only pause options are to go to the main menu or quit the game. I mean its mind boggling how many design flaws this game has while still managing to have a popular rating.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
ry 18, 2016
												The game and music are absolutely beautiful, but I think this is the rare game that would benefit by being a more traditional hidden object game. Looking for the items is nice, and there's a hint system. But then you hit the "puzzles" which are a who's who of the most boring Adventure game tropes: a game of Memory, Simon Says, a couple of simple jigsaw puzzles, a "turn the things to make various paths line up", draughts (the peg game from Cracker Barrel), and one of those "turn the dials to match everything up, but as you try to match them it messes the others up". At best, these kinds of puzzles add very little to a game, but at worst, like here, they add a completely unnecesary level of boredome and frustration. I'm all for "difficult" games like Dark Souls, but this game should have stuck the relaxing formula of other hidden object games.
